<meta name="DC.Description" content="Chelation therapy is viewed, promoted, and practiced as a form of complementary/alternative medicine (see References 1 and 21 2 ). It uses repeated intravenous administration of EDTA, usually in combination with vitamins, trace elements, and iron supplements as a treatment for a variety of diseases.3 4 5 Oral chelation therapy also has been advocated (see Reference 66 ) but will be excluded from this review. Among others, chelation therapy is claimed to be effective in reversing the arteriosclerotic disease process,7 8 in particular peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD). Proponents claim that it can be an alternative for amputation in severe cases.8 This goes back to an observation made in the 1950s, when it was noted that patients undergoing EDTA therapy for lead poisoning felt a relief of angina pectoris after this therapy.9 While various authors9 10 11 12 13 14 15 have subsequently reported promising results in uncontrolled studies, others have been unable to confirm these in similarly designed trials.16 17 The debate of whether or not it is a useful form of therapy for PAOD therefore continues.18 19 20 21 22 23 24 25 

Meanwhile, numerous clinics have been set up in Europe, the United States, and elsewhere using and promoting chelation therapy for PAOD. In the light of recent trial data, it is therefore timely to systematically review the evidence from randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trials and ask whether chelation therapy for PAOD is safe and effective.

Computerized literature searches were performed (Medline 1966 to 1996; CISCOM 1996, a database specialized in complementary/alternative medicine) to identify all studies on the subjects. Publications thus found were screened for further …" />

data-is-tab-link="true" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="title">eLetters</span></a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><div class="panel-pane pane-highwire-panel-tabs-container tabs-container--article" >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div data-panels-ajax-tab-preloaded="jnl_aha_tab_art" id="panels-ajax-tab-container-highwire_article_tabs" class="panels-ajax-tab-container"><div class="panels-ajax-tab-loading" style ="display:none"><img class="loading" src="http://circ.ahajournals.org/sites/all/modules/contrib/panels_ajax_tab/images/loading.gif" alt="Loading" title="Loading" /></div><div class="panels-ajax-tab-wrap-jnl_aha_tab_art"><div class="panel-display panel-1col clearfix" >
  <div class="panel-panel panel-col">
    <div><div class="panel-pane pane-highwire-markup" >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="highwire-markup"><div xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml" id="content-block-markup" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><div class="article fulltext-view"><span class="highwire-journal-article-marker-start"></span><ul class="kwd-group KWD"><li class="kwd"><a href="/keyword/arteriosclerosis" class="hw-term hw-article-keyword arteriosclerosis">arteriosclerosis</a></li><li class="kwd"><a href="/keyword/peripheral-vascular-disease" class="hw-term hw-article-keyword peripheral vascular disease">peripheral vascular disease</a></li><li class="kwd"><a href="/keyword/chelation-therapy" class="hw-term hw-article-keyword chelation therapy">chelation therapy</a></li></ul><p id="p-1">Chelation therapy is viewed, promoted, and practiced as a form of complementary/alternative medicine (see References 1 and 2<a id="xref-ref-1-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-1"><sup>1</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-2-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-2"><sup>2</sup></a> ). It uses repeated intravenous administration of EDTA, usually in combination with vitamins, trace elements, and iron supplements as a treatment for a variety of diseases.<a id="xref-ref-3-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-3"><sup>3</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-4-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-4"><sup>4</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-5-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-5"><sup>5</sup></a>  Oral chelation therapy also has been advocated (see Reference 6<a id="xref-ref-6-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-6"><sup>6</sup></a> ) but will be excluded from this review. Among others, chelation therapy is claimed to be effective in reversing the arteriosclerotic disease process,<a id="xref-ref-7-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-7"><sup>7</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-8-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-8"><sup>8</sup></a>  in particular peripheral arterial occlusive disease (PAOD). Proponents claim that it can be an alternative for amputation in severe cases.<a id="xref-ref-8-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-8"><sup>8</sup></a>  This goes back to an observation made in the 1950s, when it was noted that patients undergoing EDTA therapy for lead poisoning felt a relief of angina pectoris after this therapy.<a id="xref-ref-9-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-9"><sup>9</sup></a>  While various authors<a id="xref-ref-9-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-9"><sup>9</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-10-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-10"><sup>10</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-11-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-11"><sup>11</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-12-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-12"><sup>12</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-13-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-13"><sup>13</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-14-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-14"><sup>14</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-15-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-15"><sup>15</sup></a>  have subsequently reported promising results in uncontrolled studies, others have been unable to confirm these in similarly designed trials.<a id="xref-ref-16-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><sup>16</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-17-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><sup>17</sup></a>  The debate of whether or not it is a useful form of therapy for PAOD therefore continues.<a id="xref-ref-18-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-18"><sup>18</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-19-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-19"><sup>19</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-20-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-20"><sup>20</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-21-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-21"><sup>21</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-22-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-22"><sup>22</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-23-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-23"><sup>23</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-24-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-24"><sup>24</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-25-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-25"><sup>25</sup></a> </p><p id="p-2">Meanwhile, numerous clinics have been set up in Europe, the United States, and elsewhere using and promoting chelation therapy for PAOD. In the light of recent trial data, it is therefore timely to systematically review the evidence from randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind trials and ask whether chelation therapy for PAOD is safe and effective.</p><div class="section" id="sec-1">
      <h2>Methods</h2>
      <p id="p-3">Computerized literature searches were performed (Medline 1966 to 1996; CISCOM 1996, a database specialized in complementary/alternative medicine) to identify all studies on the subjects. Publications thus found were screened for further relevant articles in their bibliographies. In addition, leading experts and national societies (n=6) were contacted and asked for further material. Studies were admitted into the present review if they related to randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind clinical trials of intravenous chelation therapy for PAOD.</p>
    </div><div class="section" id="sec-2">
      <h2>Results</h2>
      <p id="p-4">Four such publications referring to three trials were found (see Table<a id="xref-table-wrap-1-1" class="xref-down-link" href="#T1"><span>⇓</span></a>). These will be discussed below. All studies relate to patients suffering from intermittent claudication.</p><div class="table pos-float" id="T1"><div class="table-inline"><div class="callout"><span>View this table:</span><ul class="callout-links"><li class="view-inline first"><a href="/" class="table-expand-inline" data-table-url="/highwire/markup/186975/expansion?postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_inline_linked_media%2Chighwire_embed&table-expand-inline=1" html="1" fragment="#" external="1" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="title">View inline</span></a></li>
<li class="view-popup last"><a href="/highwire/markup/186975/expansion?width=1000&height=500&iframe=true&postprocessors=highwire_figures%2Chighwire_math%2Chighwire_inline_linked_media%2Chighwire_embed" class="colorbox colorbox-load table-expand-popup" rel="gallery-fragment-tables" data-icon-position="" data-hide-link-title="0"><span class="title">View popup</span></a></li>
</ul></div></div><div class="table-caption"><span class="table-label">
          Table 1.
        </span> 
          <p id="p-14" class="first-child">Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Double-Blind Trials of Chelation Therapy for PAOD</p>
        <div class="sb-div caption-clear"></div></div></div>
      <p id="p-5">Olszewer and colleagues<a id="xref-ref-26-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-26"><sup>26</sup></a>  conducted a small trial (n=10) in male patients, most of them recent ex-smokers. They received either intravenous injections of Na<sub>2</sub> EDTA (10 mL) or “distilled water” (more likely saline). Both groups were also given vitamin C (2 g), vitamin B complex (2 mL), vitamin B<sub>6</sub> (300 mg), heparin (500 IU), and magnesium sulfate (1 g). Twenty treatment sessions were carried out. During the first 10 treatments, the study was conducted double blind; subsequently it was single (patient) blind. After 10 treatments, the patients in the EDTA group had substantially increased their walking distance, while in the placebo group the improvements were numerically less. Similar results could be demonstrated in ankle/arm blood pressure. The authors are unclear as to the method of data analysis and several other methodological features, rendering evaluation of this trial difficult. They state that there were no intergroup differences at the end of the double-blind phase. Notwithstanding, the authors claim, presumably on the basis of intra-group change in the experimental group (which is an inadequate way of analyzing parallel group studies), that “EDTA had a significant impact in causing the improvement.”</p>
      <p id="p-6">Guldager and coworkers<a id="xref-ref-27-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><sup>27</sup></a>  published a double-blind, placebo-controlled trial on the topic. They randomized 153 patients to receive either EDTA (3 g Na<sub>2</sub>-EDTA per treatment with vitamins and trace minerals) or placebo. Twenty treatments were carried out in each group. At the end of the 5- to 9-week treatment phase, there were no significant inter-group differences in any of the outcome parameters (arteriogram, O<sub>2</sub> pressure, subjective patient judgment). After 6 months of follow-up, this situation was unchanged.</p>
      <p id="p-7">Sloth-Nielsen et al<a id="xref-ref-28-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-28"><sup>28</sup></a>  published further results from the same trial. A subgroup (n=30) of patients had also been investigated with transcutaneous O<sub>2</sub> measurements and angiograms before and after the series of treatments. The results show no advantage for patients in the experimental group compared with the control group. On the contrary, in this subpopulation there was a (nonsignificant) trend for the maximal walking distance and the peripheral arterial pressure to increase to a greater extent in the placebo group than in the EDTA group.</p>
      <p id="p-8">Recently, another placebo-controlled, double-blind study was published.<a id="xref-ref-29-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-29"><sup>29</sup></a>  Thirty-two patients were randomized. Fifteen received 20 infusions at 500 mL, each containing 3 g disodium EDTA plus 0.76 g magnesium chloride and 0.84 g sodium bicarbonate in normal saline. Seventeen patients were treated with 20 indistinguishable saline infusions. The treatment period lasted 10 weeks, and all patients were subsequently observed for 3 months. The predefined, primary end points were subjective and objective walking distances and ankle/arm pressure. In addition, a wide range of secondary outcome measures (including subjective judgment) were included. None of these parameters showed changes to suggest that chelation therapy was superior to placebo. Subjective variables such as quality of life also did not indicate superiority of one treatment over the other. Finally, the proportion of patients who did improve did not differ in the two groups (60% versus 59%), and patients were unable to tell, at the conclusion of their series of infusions, which treatment (active or placebo) they had received.</p>
    </div><div class="section" id="sec-3">
      <h2>Comments</h2>
      <p id="p-9">Chelation therapy with EDTA binds ions in the blood. It is therefore highly effective in heavy metal poisoning,<a id="xref-ref-30-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-30"><sup>30</sup></a>  for which it is the treatment of choice. In complementary/alternative medicine, it is used with a view to extracting calcium out of arteriosclerotic plaques.<a id="xref-ref-26-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-26"><sup>26</sup></a>  It is claimed that through the chelating mechanism, it deblocks arteriosclerotic arteries and thus represents a causal treatment for arteriosclerosis, “accelerating regression” of plaques.<a id="xref-ref-11-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-11"><sup>11</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-31-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-31"><sup>31</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-32-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-32"><sup>32</sup></a>  This rationale is (at best) based on an outdated understanding of artherogenesis. There is reason to believe<a id="xref-ref-33-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-33"><sup>33</sup></a>  that proponents of chelation therapy adhere to pathophysiological models of arteriosclerosis, which are in overt discordance with our present knowledge.</p>
      <p id="p-10">An outdated (or even false) rationale does not necessarily preclude clinical effectiveness. So, does it work? The above four trials are heterogeneous in several respects. One trial<a id="xref-ref-26-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-26"><sup>26</sup></a>  is of poor quality in that it lacks methodological data essential for interpretation. The other studies<a id="xref-ref-27-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><sup>27</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-28-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-28"><sup>28</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-29-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-29"><sup>29</sup></a>  are of outstanding methodological rigor. Thus their results are convincing and definitive. Their cumulative results clearly and conclusively show that in PAOD, chelation therapy does not ameliorate symptoms (eg, prolong walking distance), nor does it change objective signs of the disease (eg, ankle/arm pressure, angiogram) or the subjective well-being (eg, activities of daily life, quality of life) to a greater extent than placebo treatment. This is true both in the short term and the long term. Thus, it is fair to say that EDTA is not an effective treatment for this condition.</p>
      <p id="p-11">Notwithstanding these indisputable facts, advocates of chelation therapy remain convinced that it works—so much so that comparative studies are conducted in which one dose of EDTA is compared with another and, on the basis of improvements in both groups, it is concluded that “EDTA is effective in treating peripheral vascular disease.”<a id="xref-ref-34-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-34"><sup>34</sup></a>  The belief in chelation therapy is also based on a “meta-analysis” of 40 studies including 22 765 patients.<a id="xref-ref-35-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><sup>35</sup></a>  This analysis refers almost exclusively to uncontrolled trials and is therefore far from compelling.</p>
      <p id="p-12">The above data also demonstrate that chelation therapy is associated with a large, positive placebo response. In one study,<a id="xref-ref-29-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-29"><sup>29</sup></a>  59% of patients in the placebo group showed a prolongation of walking distance. Thus, one might argue that chelation therapy may not be superior to placebo, yet it could still be very useful through powerful nonspecific effects. But is it? Through its chelating action, EDTA treatment is associated with severe, life-threatening adverse effects.<a id="xref-ref-27-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-27"><sup>27</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-35-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-35"><sup>35</sup></a>  In one trial, 6 patients of the experimental group showed clinical signs of (potentially lethal) hypocalcemia.<a id="xref-ref-28-3" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-28"><sup>28</sup></a>  Furthermore, there have been reports about severe kidney damage after chelation therapy.<a id="xref-ref-16-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-16"><sup>16</sup></a> <a id="xref-ref-17-2" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-17"><sup>17</sup></a>  Nonetheless, proponents of chelation therapy maintain that problems occur only when EDTA is overdosed in patients with preexisting kidney pathology.<a id="xref-ref-36-1" class="xref-bibr" href="#ref-36"><sup>36</sup></a>  Finally, harm also can be done by the needless expense, and it is therefore noteworthy that chelation therapy is usually done repeatedly over prolonged periods of time and against considerable fees.</p>
    </div><div class="section" id="sec-4">
      <h2>Conclusions</h2>
      <p id="p-13">Chelation therapy for PAOD is not superior to placebo. It is associated with considerable risks and costs. It should now be considered obsolete.</p>

        <h2 class="pane-title">About Us</h2>
    
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="jnl-aha-about-journal-snippet" id="jnl-aha-about-journal-snippet">
  
      
  <div class="snippet-content">
    <p>Our mission is to build healthier lives, free of cardiovascular diseases and stroke. That single purpose drives all we do.
